hints_html:
What integration technique works well for products?

Try integration by parts.

Use \(\displaystyle u = 5x\) and \(\displaystyle dv = \sin(x+1)\,dx\).
hints_latex: What integration technique works well for products?
hints_raw:
What integration technique works well for products?
Try integration by parts.
Use <math> \displaystyle u = 5x </math> and <math> \displaystyle dv = \sin(x+1)\,dx </math>.
question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
We proceed by integration by parts. Let \(\displaystyle u = 5x\) and \(\displaystyle dv = \sin(x+1)\,dx\) so that \(\displaystyle du = 5\) and \(\displaystyle v = -\cos(x+1)\). Then

\[\begin{aligned} \int 5x \sin(x+1)\,dx &= 5x(-\cos(x+1)) - \int 5(-\cos(x+1))\,dx\\ &= -5x\cos(x+1) +5 \int \cos(x+1)\,dx\\ &= -5x\cos(x+1) +5\sin(x+1) + C\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We proceed by integration by parts. Let $\displaystyle u = 5x$ and
$\displaystyle dv = \sin(x+1)\,dx$ so that $\displaystyle du = 5$ and
$\displaystyle v = -\cos(x+1)$. Then

\begin{align*}
\int 5x \sin(x+1)\,dx &= 5x(-\cos(x+1)) - \int 5(-\cos(x+1))\,dx\\
&= -5x\cos(x+1) +5 \int \cos(x+1)\,dx\\
&= -5x\cos(x+1) +5\sin(x+1) + C
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We proceed by integration by parts. Let <math> \displaystyle u = 5x </math> and <math> \displaystyle dv = \sin(x+1)\,dx </math> so that <math> \displaystyle du = 5 </math> and <math> \displaystyle v = -\cos(x+1) </math>. Then 

<math> 
\begin{align}
\int 5x \sin(x+1)\,dx &= 5x(-\cos(x+1)) - \int 5(-\cos(x+1))\,dx\\
&= -5x\cos(x+1) +5 \int \cos(x+1)\,dx\\
&= -5x\cos(x+1) +5\sin(x+1) + C
\end{align}
</math>
